issue.title: Can't run newer versions of docker image
issue.body:
Hi,

when I try 

```shell
docker run --rm -it -v c:\Users\john\k3s:/cluster -v c:\Users\john\k3s\ssh:/tmp/.ssh vitobotta/hetzner-k3s:v0.6.4 create-cluster --config-file /cluster/config.yaml
```

on a windows machine

with the following config.yaml:

```yaml
---
hetzner_token: <secret-token>
cluster_name: cloud1
kubeconfig_path: "/cluster/kubeconfig"
k3s_version: v1.24.4+k3s1
public_ssh_key_path: "/tmp/.ssh/id_rsa_hetz1.pub"
private_ssh_key_path: "/tmp/.ssh/id_rsa_hetz1"
ssh_allowed_networks:
  - 0.0.0.0/0
api_allowed_networks:
  - 0.0.0.0/0
verify_host_key: false
location: nbg1
schedule_workloads_on_masters: false
masters:
  instance_type: cpx21
  instance_count: 1
worker_node_pools:
- name: small
  instance_type: cpx21
  instance_count: 4
- name: big
  instance_type: cpx31
  instance_count: 1
```

(I have the public and private keys in folder ```c:\Users\john\k3s\ssh```)

I get 

```shell
Could not find rake-12.3.3 in any of the sources
Run `bundle install` to install missing gems.
```

This also happens for versions before 0.6.4, while some previous versions (such as 0.5.1) do not give this error message.

issue.title: RPC memory usage - pods OOMkilled with 4GB allocated per pod
issue.body:
<!--
  First of all, thanks for your report/suggestion/whatever!

  This template is for bug reports. If you are reporting a bug, please continue on.
  If you are here for another reason, please, go to discussions: https://github.com/anycable/anycable/discussions

  Please, check the documentation website (https://docs.anycable.io/),
  especially, the "Troubleshooting" section (https://docs.anycable.io/troubleshooting)
  before submiting the issue.
-->

### Tell us about your environment

**Ruby version:**
3.1.2

**Rails version:**
7.0.4

**`anycable` gem version:**
1.2.3

**`anycable-rails` gem version:**
1.3.3

**`grpc` gem version:**
1.45.0

### What did you do?

I have been using AnyCable for a while already, but at the moment I am doing general load tests for our app with Locust.

### What did you expect to happen?

RPC process to function correctly with 4GB of RAM allocated per process/pod (Kubernetes).

### What actually happened?

The RPC processes get OOMKilled by Kubernetes very quickly and keep restarting, despite there isn't much activity really. 

Can you advise on how much memory each RPC process is supposed to use? I think that 4GB of RAM are already a lot considering that it's a single Rails process, and I have tried lowering the threads from 40 to 20, with no success. The RPC processes get OOMKilled in a very short time from restarting, so it doesn't happen after a while. Seems like a memory leak or something like that.

Thanks in advance for your help!

comment.body: Thanks @palkan , if it happens again I will try a different version of that gem.

pull_request.body:
Increase of subnet mask to 24 would gives the possibility to add vSwitch to the network. Currently the network and only existing subnet have the same subnet mask and therefor any other subnet has an overlap and is denied.
With a vSwitch I could probably connect a dedicated server to the cloud.

issue.title: locust k8s operator
issue.body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
Need for flexible, secure and easy to use distributed performance testing solution while enabling keeping in mind points like; cloud governance, k8s resource management, CI compatibility. 


### Describe the solution you'd like
A k8s operator

### Describe alternatives you've considered
HELM. However, this is not optimal as it requires a lot of manipulation and dealing with a lot of different k8s resource types not to mention lack of governance when deployed in an organisation. 

 
### Additional context
In my company, we were interested in cloud based distributed performance testing. We ended up choosing “locust” as a tool and I wrote a kubernetes operator for it. As far as I know and searched, this simply doesn’t exist for locust today.The operator have been running on AWS EKS for months now and it is very stable and performant.

The project was created to provide:
- A friendly user interface "A simple k8s custom resource based on a CRD"
- Ability to run a distributed performance testing
- Only ask for needed cluster permissions (security) 
- Exposing a Prometheus endpoint for test metrics
- Maintain cloud infrastructure governance i.e. when used in an organisation,  it is possible to maintain the governance over the allocated / created resources. 
- Cloud native by design 
- Enablement of performance testing in CI / CD pipelines

The project was inspired after doing an industry study / survey. 
The project was influenced in functionality by the k6 k8s operator.

As the code really doesn't include anything exclusive to the company, Open sourcing it is not a problem and it is something that I would happily do. 

What is the "catch"? 
The only "catch" is that the project is written in Java. That being said, from a user perspective, the interface purely through k8s and users are not exposed to any java code.  This is similar to how k8s and most operators are written in Go but non of k8s users need to know anything about Go. 

Looking forward to your feedback.

comment.body: Hi @AbdelrhmanHamouda ! This looks amazing! I checked the docs and would like to give it a try. How do I open the UI when a test is running?

issue.title: Document labels used by Okteto pods
Invalid Hetzner Cloud token
issue.body:
Hi,

I appreciate your work a lot, I got me going with k3s and I using it constantly for learning purposes. I'm using your project for about a year now and it worked great until I upgraded my hetzner-k3s binary (running on Linux). No matter what I do, I get the error:  Invalid Hetzner Cloud token.

I ran: 
- `hetzner-k3s create-cluster --config-file=config.yaml`
- `hetzner-k3s upgrade-cluster --config-file=config.yaml --new-k3s-version v1.24.4+k3s1`
- I created the config file from scratch by using the example from the instructions
- Created a few new Hetzner Projects and API Tokens at them with read and write permissions
- I checked my env vars (HCLOUD_TOKEN is not set)
- Tried with and without qoutes around the token in the config file
- I tested the Hetzner API by running `curl  -H "Authorization: Bearer $API_TOKEN"   'https://api.hetzner.cloud/v1/server_types'` with the API Token and that works fine. 
- I tried versions 0.6.0 until 0.6.5.pre1
- I even tried the docker version

In al cases I get the error: 
```
Some information in the configuration file requires your attention:
 - Invalid Hetzner Cloud token
```

I hope I didn't make a simple mistake. Do you have any idea what the problem can be?

Thanks in advance

issue.title: Document labels used by Okteto pods
issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Documentation request

**Describe the solution you'd like**
In my case, I use a wrapper around some K8s tools including Okteto to abstract some complexity, and am also using KEDA autoscaling to scale my app. When I start Okteto, the autoscaler interferes because it automatically starts its own non-Okteto pods, so traffic is then split between Okteto pods and the autoscaler pods, causing problems and confusion. For this reason, I changed my CLI so that before starting Okteto it patches the services so that they send traffic only to the Okteto pods, ignoring the autoscaled pods. So I can work with Okteto just fine. 

This wasn't documented, so I had to figure out that Okteto labels the pod for the main service with the label "interactive.dev.okteto.com" and the additional services (as specified in the manifest) with "detached.dev.okteto.com".

By patching my services to use these labels during an Okteto session, I no longer have problems due to the autoscaling.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I couldn't think of an alternative

comment.body: *_ssh_key_path settings require a relative path. The way you set them, the tool will look for the keys in the same directory where it is running. So you should specify the correct path where they are stored, such as ~/.ssh/id_rsa for example if they are in the home directory as usual.

issue.title: post_create_commands and additional_packages
issue.body:
So, I have added to my config file code bellow. But I see also ability add some packages with `additional_packages`. How that works in different OS? and what about lifecycle? As I understand post_create_commands will be last one for running? If I want to update or add extra nodes will be additional_packages and post_create_commands run for active nodes? 

and how I can labeled nodes in setup way? Does it works https://github.com/vitobotta/hetzner-k3s/issues/98 ?

```
post_create_commands:
- apt update && apt upgrade -y
# Fix for K3s on Debian (Pods can't be scheduled)
- apt -y install apparmor apparmor-utils
#
- apt -y install mc htop vim wget git zsh podman iftop atop lsof fail2ban jq make
#
- apt -y install tmux tmuxinator
- git clone https://github.com/gpakosz/.tmux.git /root/.tmux ; ln -s -f /root/.tmux/.tmux.conf /root/ ; cp /root/.tmux/.tmux.conf.local /root/
#
- sh -c "$(wget https://raw.github.com/ohmyzsh/ohmyzsh/master/tools/install.sh -O -)" -y
- sed -i 's/\/bin\/bash/\/usr\/bin\/zsh/g' /etc/passwd
- /usr/bin/git clone https://github.com/zsh-users/zsh-autosuggestions /root/.oh-my-zsh/custom/plugins/zsh-autosuggestions
- sed -i 's/plugins=(git)/plugins=(zsh-autosuggestions git docker docker-compose poetry kubectl)/g' /root/.zshrc
#
- apt autoremove -y
- shutdown -r now
```

comment.body: @maxclax Nice to hear that you haven't had any problems with the binaries, other people have. Ruby isn't really great for this since it's not compiled, that's why I am rewriting it in Crystal.

comment.body:
Hi, 

- installing packages you specify happens only once the nodes are first created. If you want to upgrade them or install something else after the fact, you need to SSH into the nodes and do it manually.
- The machines are provided by default with Ubuntu unless you specify another image, so the packages and the commands you specify should match that
- If you add new nodes to an existing cluster, it will run the post commands and install the additional packages on them as expected
- the node labelling was introduced in v0.6.2 IIRC but I recommend you use the gem because there are some issues with the binaries. I am currently rewriting the tool in Crystal to be able to offer proper binaries and solve some other issues I have with the Ruby version. If you have problems with 0.6.2 I recommend you stick to a release from before I introduced this changes, 0.5.9 and label the nodes manually for now.

issue.title: overwriting  ~/.kube/config data
issue.body: I have some clusters/context in my config file ~/.kube/config. But after create new cluster by hetzner-k3s all my config changed only with new data of new cluster. How can I create new cluster with add new data like new context, not cleaning previous data of clusters.

comment.body: Hi, that should not happen. The tool writes the kubeconfig to the file you specify in the config file. Did you set it to ~/.kube/config? I recommend to specify another file, maybe in the same locations as the config file, and then manually copy it to whereever you want.

issue.title: Use of cache doesn't seem to speed up much
issue.body:
## Expected Behavior

Using cache should improve performance significantly.

## Actual Behavior

For example I have an endpoint that serializes 7700 records that also include associations. The queries are fast, but generating the serialized response takes 5 seconds at least (I'm already using the oj gem).

I have enabled caching and I can see it creates one individual Redis key for each record and for its associated records too.
But the serialization takes more or less the same time basically.

## Steps to Reproduce the Problem

  1. Add caching configuration to the relevant models (main model as well as the associated models)
  2. Run the serializer the first time, it creates the keys in Redis
  3. Run the serializer the second time with the same data, this is not faster than without caching

## Specifications

  - Version: 2.2.0
  - Ruby version: 3.1.2


Thanks in advance.

comment.body: Hi @stas, thanks for the quick reply. I thought someone it would fetch multiple keys at once. I will try some other caching method. Thanks!

issue.title: Use of cache doesn't seem to speed up much
issue.body:
## Expected Behavior

Using cache should improve performance significantly.

## Actual Behavior

For example I have an endpoint that serializes 7700 records that also include associations. The queries are fast, but generating the serialized response takes 5 seconds at least (I'm already using the oj gem).

I have enabled caching and I can see it creates one individual Redis key for each record and for its associated records too.
But the serialization takes more or less the same time basically.

## Steps to Reproduce the Problem

  1. Add caching configuration to the relevant models (main model as well as the associated models)
  2. Run the serializer the first time, it creates the keys in Redis
  3. Run the serializer the second time with the same data, this is not faster than without caching

## Specifications

  - Version: 2.2.0
  - Ruby version: 3.1.2


Thanks in advance.

NGINX Ingress controller

**Helm version:**
version.BuildInfo{Version:"v3.7.0", GitCommit:"eeac83883cb4014fe60267ec6373570374ce770b", GitTreeState:"clean", GoVersion:"go1.16.8"}

**Environment:**
- Cloud provider or hardware configuration: GCP GKE
- OS (e.g. from /etc/os-release): Container-Optimized OS from Google 
- Kernel version: 5.4.144+

How was the ingress-nginx-controller installed:
Using helm template , using the command: 

`helm install ingress-nginx ingress-nginx/ingress-nginx --set controller.extraArgs.size-buckets="{0.05,0.1,0.3,0.5,1.0,5,10}"`

Output of 'helm ls -A | grep -i ingress'
ingress-nginx	default  	1       	2022-02-10 12:35:46.167462946 +0200 EET	deployed	ingress-nginx-4.0.17	1.1.1 

**Current State of the controller**:
```
➜  kubectl get pod
NAME                                        READY   STATUS             RESTARTS   AGE
ingress-nginx-controller-7bdc9d4dc8-dtkc2   0/1     CrashLoopBackOff   10         27m
```

```
➜  kubectl describe ingressclasses
Name:         nginx
Labels:       app.kubernetes.io/component=controller
              app.kubernetes.io/instance=ingress-nginx
              app.kubernetes.io/managed-by=Helm
              app.kubernetes.io/name=ingress-nginx
              app.kubernetes.io/part-of=ingress-nginx

              meta.helm.sh/release-namespace: default
Controller:   k8s.io/ingress-nginx
Events:       <none>

```

NGINX Ingress controller

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

unknown flag: --size-buckets
Usage of :
unknown flag: --size-buckets
.....
.....
```

**What happened**:

I installed ingress-nginx using helm and tried to set the flag **size-buckets** as it looks that it exists https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/blob/main/cmd/nginx/flags.go and according that feature described here https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/pull/7171.

The ingress-nginx deployment is successful but the pod is not starting and get the following message in pod logs "unknown flag: --size-buckets".

If try to use other flag, e.g. "enable-metrics" it works and accept the flag.

According the documentation at https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/blob/main/docs/user-guide/cli-arguments.md, the flags time-buckets, length-buckets, size-buckets are not listed in list of arguments. 

So the question is, how can I set these flags?

issue.title: Invalid Hetzner Cloud token
issue.body:
Hi,

I appreciate your work a lot, I got me going with k3s and I using it constantly for learning purposes. I'm using your project for about a year now and it worked great until I upgraded my hetzner-k3s binary (running on Linux). No matter what I do, I get the error:  Invalid Hetzner Cloud token.

I ran: 
- `hetzner-k3s create-cluster --config-file=config.yaml`
- `hetzner-k3s upgrade-cluster --config-file=config.yaml --new-k3s-version v1.24.4+k3s1`
- I created the config file from scratch by using the example from the instructions
- Created a few new Hetzner Projects and API Tokens at them with read and write permissions
- I checked my env vars (HCLOUD_TOKEN is not set)
- Tried with and without qoutes around the token in the config file
- I tested the Hetzner API by running `curl  -H "Authorization: Bearer $API_TOKEN"   'https://api.hetzner.cloud/v1/server_types'` with the API Token and that works fine. 
- I tried versions 0.6.0 until 0.6.5.pre1
- I even tried the docker version

In al cases I get the error: 
```
Some information in the configuration file requires your attention:
 - Invalid Hetzner Cloud token
```

I hope I didn't make a simple mistake. Do you have any idea what the problem can be?

Thanks in advance

comment.body: @opsdevit-nl for now yes use an older version. I have started rewriting it in Rust already so the new version should solve several issues.

issue.title: Invalid Hetzner Cloud token
issue.body:
Hi,

I appreciate your work a lot, I got me going with k3s and I using it constantly for learning purposes. I'm using your project for about a year now and it worked great until I upgraded my hetzner-k3s binary (running on Linux). No matter what I do, I get the error:  Invalid Hetzner Cloud token.

I ran: 
- `hetzner-k3s create-cluster --config-file=config.yaml`
- `hetzner-k3s upgrade-cluster --config-file=config.yaml --new-k3s-version v1.24.4+k3s1`
- I created the config file from scratch by using the example from the instructions
- Created a few new Hetzner Projects and API Tokens at them with read and write permissions
- I checked my env vars (HCLOUD_TOKEN is not set)
- Tried with and without qoutes around the token in the config file
- I tested the Hetzner API by running `curl  -H "Authorization: Bearer $API_TOKEN"   'https://api.hetzner.cloud/v1/server_types'` with the API Token and that works fine. 
- I tried versions 0.6.0 until 0.6.5.pre1
- I even tried the docker version

In al cases I get the error: 
```
Some information in the configuration file requires your attention:
 - Invalid Hetzner Cloud token
```

I hope I didn't make a simple mistake. Do you have any idea what the problem can be?

Thanks in advance

comment.body: On a side note, I think I have (almost) decided to rewrite the tool in Rust because while Ruby is my favorite, it's not really the best for these things because you cannot package it easily etc. I am gonna spend some time on it during the weekend to play with this option.

issue.title: status keeps looping forever??
issue.body:
I just spin up a small cluster (3 master + 3 workers), all servers created in Hetzner project, all good. 
But in terminal it keeps rolling like below for nearly 1 hour now. 
Inside Hetzner itself, it all looks ok and servers are marked "green". 

Where can I see why terminal keeps waiting forever or not seeing the real status? 
Side note: I used the latest stable k3s version (if that matters?)
k3s_version: v1.24.4+k3s1


```
Waiting for server test-cpx21-pool-workerpool-worker1 to be up...
Waiting for server test-cpx21-pool-workerpool-worker2 to be up...

comment.body:
I actually did a release already, 0.6.4, which allows you to enable debug logging for SSH connections by setting the environment variable to true

```bash
export SSH_DEBUG=true
```

Run this before creating the cluster and it should produce quite a lot of output which may help find the cause of the issue.

The gem, the binaries, the Homebrew formula and the Docker image have been updated already.

Thanks in advance for checking it out.

Weird, I have never added my SSH key to keychain and I have never been able to reproduce these issues. So annoying....

Tomorrow (time permitting) I will try to produce prerelease binaries with some more debug logging, hoping it might help to find the cause of these issues.

In the meantime, since the standalone binaries are a pretty new thing and might still have issues, do you have a chance to test creating clusters with the regular Ruby gem using  a normal Ruby 2.7.1 environment instead of the standalone binaries? Or with Docker if you cannot set up Ruby. Just to see if the problem occurs only with the standalone binaries.

I wish I were able to reproduce the issue here, it would be much easier to investigate.

issue.title: status keeps looping forever??
issue.body:
I just spin up a small cluster (3 master + 3 workers), all servers created in Hetzner project, all good. 
But in terminal it keeps rolling like below for nearly 1 hour now. 
Inside Hetzner itself, it all looks ok and servers are marked "green". 

Where can I see why terminal keeps waiting forever or not seeing the real status? 
Side note: I used the latest stable k3s version (if that matters?)
k3s_version: v1.24.4+k3s1


```
Waiting for server test-cpx21-pool-workerpool-worker1 to be up...
Waiting for server test-cpx21-pool-workerpool-worker2 to be up...
Waiting for server test-cpx21-master3 to be up...
Waiting for server test-cpx21-master1 to be up...
Waiting for server test-cpx21-master2 to be up...
Waiting for server test-cpx21-pool-workerpool-worker3 to be up...
Waiting for server test-cpx21-pool-workerpool-worker1 to be up...
Waiting for server test-cpx21-pool-workerpool-worker2 to be up...
Waiting for server test-cpx21-master3 to be up...
Waiting for server test-cpx21-master1 to be up...
Waiting for server test-cpx21-master2 to be up...
Waiting for server test-cpx21-master3 to be up...
Waiting for server test-cpx21-pool-workerpool-worker3 to be up...
Waiting for server test-cpx21-pool-workerpool-worker2 to be up...
Waiting for server test-cpx21-pool-workerpool-worker1 to be up...
Waiting for server test-cpx21-master1 to be up...
Waiting for server test-cpx21-master2 to be up...
Waiting for server test-cpx21-pool-workerpool-worker3 to be up...
Waiting for server test-cpx21-pool-workerpool-worker2 to be up...
Waiting for server test-cpx21-master3 to be up...
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7568546/187703890-08866329-6b3d-4fa3-a191-c3bcf1341e8e.png)

comment.body:
Hi, another user was having the same problem and from an initial investigation it looked like some kind of a problem with SSH connections, probably due to some keys or something like that. I haven't been able to reproduce the issue myself unfortunately and that person decided not to use Kubernetes so they can't help, but maybe you can.

Can you give me more details on how you installed the tool, which OS and architecture and what kind of SSH key you are using?

issue.title: releases subcommand throws error on Linux
issue.body:
I read your request on the GoRails Discord to test the Linux version. I'm getting this on Manjaro Linux:

```
➜ hetzner-k3s version                
0.6.1

➜ hetzner-k3s releases
Cannot fetch the releases with Github API, please try again later. This may be due to API rate limits.
Traceback (most recent call last):
	5: from /__enclose_io_memfs__/local/exe/hetzner-k3s:7:in `<main>'
	4: from /__enclose_io_memfs__/lib/ruby/gems/2.7.0/gems/thor-1.2.1/lib/thor/base.rb:485:in `start'
	3: from /__enclose_io_memfs__/lib/ruby/gems/2.7.0/gems/thor-1.2.1/lib/thor.rb:392:in `dispatch'
	2: from /__enclose_io_memfs__/lib/ruby/gems/2.7.0/gems/thor-1.2.1/lib/thor/invocation.rb:127:in `invoke_command'
	1: from /__enclose_io_memfs__/lib/ruby/gems/2.7.0/gems/thor-1.2.1/lib/thor/command.rb:27:in `run'
/__enclose_io_memfs__/local/lib/hetzner/k3s/cli.rb:52:in `releases': undefined method `each' for nil:NilClass (NoMethodError)
```

I didn't touch my laptop in hours before installing the application, so it can't be a rate limit issue.

issue.title: Can't run newer versions of docker image
issue.body:
Hi,

when I try 

```shell
docker run --rm -it -v c:\Users\john\k3s:/cluster -v c:\Users\john\k3s\ssh:/tmp/.ssh vitobotta/hetzner-k3s:v0.6.4 create-cluster --config-file /cluster/config.yaml
```

on a windows machine

with the following config.yaml:

```yaml
---
hetzner_token: <secret-token>
cluster_name: cloud1
kubeconfig_path: "/cluster/kubeconfig"
k3s_version: v1.24.4+k3s1
public_ssh_key_path: "/tmp/.ssh/id_rsa_hetz1.pub"
private_ssh_key_path: "/tmp/.ssh/id_rsa_hetz1"
ssh_allowed_networks:
  - 0.0.0.0/0
api_allowed_networks:
  - 0.0.0.0/0
verify_host_key: false
location: nbg1
schedule_workloads_on_masters: false
masters:
  instance_type: cpx21
  instance_count: 1
worker_node_pools:
- name: small
  instance_type: cpx21
  instance_count: 4
- name: big
  instance_type: cpx31
  instance_count: 1
```

(I have the public and private keys in folder ```c:\Users\john\k3s\ssh```)

I get 

```shell
Could not find rake-12.3.3 in any of the sources
Run `bundle install` to install missing gems.
```

This also happens for versions before 0.6.4, while some previous versions (such as 0.5.1) do not give this error message.

comment.body:
@dmitrylavrenov  @QuentinBellus The project is alive, I am just busy with work. I have started rewriting the tool in Crystal so to be able to offer proper standalone binaries so you don't need to use Docker or the Ruby gem.

For the time being can you please try with the regular Ruby gem?

issue.title: RPC memory usage - pods OOMkilled with 4GB allocated per pod
issue.body:
<!--
  First of all, thanks for your report/suggestion/whatever!

  This template is for bug reports. If you are reporting a bug, please continue on.
  If you are here for another reason, please, go to discussions: https://github.com/anycable/anycable/discussions

  Please, check the documentation website (https://docs.anycable.io/),
  especially, the "Troubleshooting" section (https://docs.anycable.io/troubleshooting)
  before submiting the issue.
-->

### Tell us about your environment

**Ruby version:**
3.1.2

**Rails version:**
7.0.4

**`anycable` gem version:**
1.2.3

**`anycable-rails` gem version:**
1.3.3

**`grpc` gem version:**
1.45.0

### What did you do?

I have been using AnyCable for a while already, but at the moment I am doing general load tests for our app with Locust.

### What did you expect to happen?

RPC process to function correctly with 4GB of RAM allocated per process/pod (Kubernetes).

### What actually happened?

The RPC processes get OOMKilled by Kubernetes very quickly and keep restarting, despite there isn't much activity really. 

Can you advise on how much memory each RPC process is supposed to use? I think that 4GB of RAM are already a lot considering that it's a single Rails process, and I have tried lowering the threads from 40 to 20, with no success. The RPC processes get OOMKilled in a very short time from restarting, so it doesn't happen after a while. Seems like a memory leak or something like that.

Thanks in advance for your help!

comment.body: Thanks @palkan , if it happens again I will try a different version of that gem.

commits.message:
Merge pull request #110 from cwilhelm/main

Increase subnet mask to 24

pull_request.title: Increase subnet mask to 24
pull_request.body:
Increase of subnet mask to 24 would gives the possibility to add vSwitch to the network. Currently the network and only existing subnet have the same subnet mask and therefor any other subnet has an overlap and is denied.
With a vSwitch I could probably connect a dedicated server to the cloud.

### Tell us about your environment

**Ruby version:**
3.1.2

**Rails version:**
7.0.4

**`anycable` gem version:**
1.2.3

**`anycable-rails` gem version:**
1.3.3

**`grpc` gem version:**
1.45.0

### What did you do?

I have been using AnyCable for a while already, but at the moment I am doing general load tests for our app with Locust.

### What did you expect to happen?

RPC process to function correctly with 4GB of RAM allocated per process/pod (Kubernetes).

### What actually happened?

The RPC processes get OOMKilled by Kubernetes very quickly and keep restarting, despite there isn't much activity really. 

Can you advise on how much memory each RPC process is supposed to use? I think that 4GB of RAM are already a lot considering that it's a single Rails process, and I have tried lowering the threads from 40 to 20, with no success. The RPC processes get OOMKilled in a very short time from restarting, so it doesn't happen after a while. Seems like a memory leak or something like that.

Thanks in advance for your help!

issue.title: locust k8s operator
issue.body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
Need for flexible, secure and easy to use distributed performance testing solution while enabling keeping in mind points like; cloud governance, k8s resource management, CI compatibility. 


### Describe the solution you'd like
A k8s operator

### Describe alternatives you've considered
HELM. However, this is not optimal as it requires a lot of manipulation and dealing with a lot of different k8s resource types not to mention lack of governance when deployed in an organisation. 

 
### Additional context
In my company, we were interested in cloud based distributed performance testing. We ended up choosing “locust” as a tool and I wrote a kubernetes operator for it. As far as I know and searched, this simply doesn’t exist for locust today.The operator have been running on AWS EKS for months now and it is very stable and performant.

The project was created to provide:
- A friendly user interface "A simple k8s custom resource based on a CRD"
- Ability to run a distributed performance testing
- Only ask for needed cluster permissions (security) 
- Exposing a Prometheus endpoint for test metrics
- Maintain cloud infrastructure governance i.e. when used in an organisation,  it is possible to maintain the governance over the allocated / created resources. 
- Cloud native by design 
- Enablement of performance testing in CI / CD pipelines

The project was inspired after doing an industry study / survey. 
The project was influenced in functionality by the k6 k8s operator.

As the code really doesn't include anything exclusive to the company, Open sourcing it is not a problem and it is something that I would happily do. 

What is the "catch"? 
The only "catch" is that the project is written in Java. That being said, from a user perspective, the interface purely through k8s and users are not exposed to any java code.  This is similar to how k8s and most operators are written in Go but non of k8s users need to know anything about Go. 

Looking forward to your feedback.

issue.title: Document labels used by Okteto pods
issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Documentation request

**Describe the solution you'd like**
In my case, I use a wrapper around some K8s tools including Okteto to abstract some complexity, and am also using KEDA autoscaling to scale my app. When I start Okteto, the autoscaler interferes because it automatically starts its own non-Okteto pods, so traffic is then split between Okteto pods and the autoscaler pods, causing problems and confusion. For this reason, I changed my CLI so that before starting Okteto it patches the services so that they send traffic only to the Okteto pods, ignoring the autoscaled pods. So I can work with Okteto just fine. 

This wasn't documented, so I had to figure out that Okteto labels the pod for the main service with the label "interactive.dev.okteto.com" and the additional services (as specified in the manifest) with "detached.dev.okteto.com".

By patching my services to use these labels during an Okteto session, I no longer have problems due to the autoscaling.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I couldn't think of an alternative

comment.body: *_ssh_key_path settings require a relative path. The way you set them, the tool will look for the keys in the same directory where it is running. comment.body:
Hi, 

- installing packages you specify happens only once the nodes are first created. If you want to upgrade them or install something else after the fact, you need to SSH into the nodes and do it manually.
- The machines are provided by default with Ubuntu unless you specify another image, so the packages and the commands you specify should match that
- If you add new nodes to an existing cluster, it will run the post commands and install the additional packages on them as expected
- the node labelling was introduced in v0.6.2 IIRC but I recommend you use the gem because there are some issues with the binaries. I am currently rewriting the tool in Crystal to be able to offer proper binaries and solve some other issues I have with the Ruby version. If you have problems with 0.6.2 I recommend you stick to a release from before I introduced this changes, 0.5.9 and label the nodes manually for now.

issue.title: Use of cache doesn't seem to speed up much
issue.body:
## Expected Behavior

Using cache should improve performance significantly.

## Actual Behavior

For example I have an endpoint that serializes 7700 records that also include associations. The queries are fast, but generating the serialized response takes 5 seconds at least (I'm already using the oj gem).

I have enabled caching and I can see it creates one individual Redis key for each record and for its associated records too.
But the serialization takes more or less the same time basically.

## Steps to Reproduce the Problem

  1. Add caching configuration to the relevant models (main model as well as the associated models)
  2. Run the serializer the first time, it creates the keys in Redis
  3. Run the serializer the second time with the same data, this is not faster than without caching

## Specifications

  - Version: 2.2.0
  - Ruby version: 3.1.2


Thanks in advance.

NGINX Ingress controller
Release: v1.1.1
nginx version: nginx/1.19.9

**Kubernetes version (use kubectl version):**

**Helm version:**
version.BuildInfo{Version:"v3.7.0", GitCommit:"eeac83883cb4014fe60267ec6373570374ce770b", GitTreeState:"clean", GoVersion:"go1.16.8"}

**Environment:**
- Cloud provider or hardware configuration: GCP GKE
- OS (e.g. from /etc/os-release): Container-Optimized OS from Google 
- Kernel version: 5.4.144+

How was the ingress-nginx-controller installed:
Using helm template , using the command: 

`helm install ingress-nginx ingress-nginx/ingress-nginx --set controller.extraArgs.size-buckets="{0.05,0.1,0.3,0.5,1.0,5,10}"`

Output of 'helm ls -A | grep -i ingress'

ingress-nginx-controller-7bdc9d4dc8-dtkc2   0/1     CrashLoopBackOff   10         27m

```

Name:         nginx
Labels:       app.kubernetes.io/component=controller
              app.kubernetes.io/instance=ingress-nginx

**What happened**:

I installed ingress-nginx using helm and tried to set the flag **size-buckets** as it looks that it exists https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/blob/main/cmd/nginx/flags.go and according that feature described here https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/pull/7171.

The ingress-nginx deployment is successful but the pod is not starting and get the following message in pod logs "unknown flag: --size-buckets".

If try to use other flag, e.g. "enable-metrics" it works and accept the flag.

According the documentation at https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/blob/main/docs/user-guide/cli-arguments.md, the flags time-buckets, length-buckets, size-buckets are not listed in list of arguments.

issue.title: Can't run newer versions of docker image
issue.body:
Hi,

when I try 

```shell
docker run --rm -it -v c:\Users\john\k3s:/cluster -v c:\Users\john\k3s\ssh:/tmp/.ssh vitobotta/hetzner-k3s:v0.6.4 create-cluster --config-file /cluster/config.yaml
```

on a windows machine

with the following config.yaml:

```yaml
---
hetzner_token: <secret-token>
cluster_name: cloud1
kubeconfig_path: "/cluster/kubeconfig"
k3s_version: v1.24.4+k3s1
public_ssh_key_path: "/tmp/.ssh/id_rsa_hetz1.pub"
private_ssh_key_path: "/tmp/.ssh/id_rsa_hetz1"
ssh_allowed_networks:
  - 0.0.0.0/0
api_allowed_networks:
  - 0.0.0.0/0
verify_host_key: false
location: nbg1
schedule_workloads_on_masters: false
masters:
  instance_type: cpx21
  instance_count: 1
worker_node_pools:
- name: small
  instance_type: cpx21
  instance_count: 4
- name: big
  instance_type: cpx31
  instance_count: 1
```

(I have the public and private keys in folder ```c:\Users\john\k3s\ssh```)

I get 

```shell
Could not find rake-12.3.3 in any of the sources
Run `bundle install` to install missing gems.
```

This also happens for versions before 0.6.4, while some previous versions (such as 0.5.1) do not give this error message.

comment.body: Hi, I am in the process of rewriting the tool in Crystal to be able to more easily offer standalone executables since I've had problems doing this with Ruby. Can you use 0.5.9 for the time being?

comment.body: Hi, unfortunately there are some issues with the latest versions introduced with changes I made to be able to offer standalone binaries. I recommend you use v0.5.9 for the time being as I am busy rewriting the tool in Crystal. Rewriting in Crystal makes it easier to produce standalone binaries that will make using the tool easier, since you won't need to set up a Ruby environment or use the Docker image anymore. But this is still a work in progress, so for now please use v0.5.9. Thanks

payload.description: A Ruby gem (and Docker image) to install and manage Kubernetes clusters in Hetzner Cloud using the lightweight distribution k3s by Rancher.

issue.title: Invalid Hetzner Cloud token
issue.body:
Hi,

I appreciate your work a lot, I got me going with k3s and I using it constantly for learning purposes. I'm using your project for about a year now and it worked great until I upgraded my hetzner-k3s binary (running on Linux). No matter what I do, I get the error:  Invalid Hetzner Cloud token.

I ran: 
- `hetzner-k3s create-cluster --config-file=config.yaml`
- `hetzner-k3s upgrade-cluster --config-file=config.yaml --new-k3s-version v1.24.4+k3s1`
- I created the config file from scratch by using the example from the instructions
- Created a few new Hetzner Projects and API Tokens at them with read and write permissions
- I checked my env vars (HCLOUD_TOKEN is not set)
- Tried with and without qoutes around the token in the config file
- I tested the Hetzner API by running `curl  -H "Authorization: Bearer $API_TOKEN"   'https://api.hetzner.cloud/v1/server_types'` with the API Token and that works fine. 
- I tried versions 0.6.0 until 0.6.5.pre1
- I even tried the docker version

In al cases I get the error: 
```
Some information in the configuration file requires your attention:
 - Invalid Hetzner Cloud token
```

I hope I didn't make a simple mistake. Do you have any idea what the problem can be?

Thanks in advance

comment.body: @opsdevit-nl for now yes use an older version. I have started rewriting it in Rust already so the new version should solve several issues.

- I created the config file from scratch by using the example from the instructions

- I checked my env vars (HCLOUD_TOKEN is not set)
- Tried with and without qoutes around the token in the config file
- I tested the Hetzner API by running `curl  -H "Authorization: Bearer $API_TOKEN"   'https://api.hetzner.cloud/v1/server_types'` with the API Token and that works fine. 
- I tried versions 0.6.0 until 0.6.5.pre1
- I even tried the docker version

In al cases I get the error: 
```
Some information in the configuration file requires your attention:
 - Invalid Hetzner Cloud token
```

I hope I didn't make a simple mistake. Do you have any idea what the problem can be?

Thanks in advance

comment.body: On a side note, I think I have (almost) decided to rewrite the tool in Rust because while Ruby is my favorite, it's not really the best for these things because you cannot package it easily etc. I am gonna spend some time on it during the weekend to play with this option.

issue.title: Invalid Hetzner Cloud token
issue.body:
Hi,

I appreciate your work a lot, I got me going with k3s and I using it constantly for learning purposes. I'm using your project for about a year now and I worked great until I upgraded my hetzner-k3s binary (running on Linux). No matter what I do, I get the error:  Invalid Hetzner Cloud token.

I ran: 
- `hetzner-k3s create-cluster --config-file=config.yaml`
- `hetzner-k3s upgrade-cluster --config-file=config.yaml --new-k3s-version v1.24.4+k3s1`
- I created the config file from scratch by using the example from the instructions
- Created a few new Hetzner Projects and API Tokens at them with read and write permissions
- I checked my env vars (HCLOUD_TOKEN is not set)
- Tried with and without qoutes around the token in the config file
- I tested the Hetzner API by running `curl  -H "Authorization: Bearer $API_TOKEN"   'https://api.hetzner.cloud/v1/server_types'` with the API Token and that works fine. 
- I tried versions 0.6.0 until 0.6.5.pre1
- I even tried the docker version

In al cases I get the error: 
```
Some information in the configuration file requires your attention:
 - Invalid Hetzner Cloud token
```

I hope I didn't make a simple mistake. Do you have any idea what the problem can be?

Thanks in advance

issue.body:

But in terminal it keeps rolling like below for nearly 1 hour now.

comment.body:
I actually did a release already, 0.6.4, which allows you to enable debug logging for SSH connections by setting the environment variable to true

```bash
export SSH_DEBUG=true
```

Run this before creating the cluster and it should produce quite a lot of output which may help find the cause of the issue.

The gem, the binaries, the Homebrew formula and the Docker image have been updated already.

Thanks in advance for checking it out.

payload.description: A Ruby gem (and Docker image) to install and manage Kubernetes clusters in Hetzner Cloud using the lightweight distribution k3s by Rancher.

commits.message: Make it possible to enable debug logging for SSH

comment.body:
Weird, I have never added my SSH key to keychain and I have never been able to reproduce these issues. So annoying....

Tomorrow (time permitting) I will try to produce prerelease binaries with some more debug logging, hoping it might help to find the cause of these issues.

In the meantime, since the standalone binaries are a pretty new thing and might still have issues, do you have a chance to test creating clusters with the regular Ruby gem using  a normal Ruby 2.7.1 environment instead of the standalone binaries? Or with Docker if you cannot set up Ruby. Just to see if the problem occurs only with the standalone binaries.

I wish I were able to reproduce the issue here, it would be much easier to investigate.

issue.title: Can't run newer versions of docker image
issue.body:
Hi,

when I try 

```shell
docker run --rm -it -v c:\Users\john\k3s:/cluster -v c:\Users\john\k3s\ssh:/tmp/.ssh vitobotta/hetzner-k3s:v0.6.4 create-cluster --config-file /cluster/config.yaml
```

on a windows machine

with the following config.yaml:

```yaml
---
hetzner_token: <secret-token>
cluster_name: cloud1
kubeconfig_path: "/cluster/kubeconfig"
k3s_version: v1.24.4+k3s1
public_ssh_key_path: "/tmp/.ssh/id_rsa_hetz1.pub"
private_ssh_key_path: "/tmp/.ssh/id_rsa_hetz1"
ssh_allowed_networks:
  - 0.0.0.0/0
api_allowed_networks:
  - 0.0.0.0/0
verify_host_key: false
location: nbg1
schedule_workloads_on_masters: false
masters:
  instance_type: cpx21
  instance_count: 1
worker_node_pools:
- name: small
  instance_type: cpx21
  instance_count: 4
- name: big
  instance_type: cpx31
  instance_count: 1
```

(I have the public and private keys in folder ```c:\Users\john\k3s\ssh```)

I get 

```shell
Could not find rake-12.3.3 in any of the sources
Run `bundle install` to install missing gems.
```

This also happens for versions before 0.6.4, while some previous versions (such as 0.5.1) do not give this error message.

issue.title: RPC memory usage - pods OOMkilled with 4GB allocated per pod
issue.body:
<!--
  First of all, thanks for your report/suggestion/whatever!

  This template is for bug reports. If you are reporting a bug, please continue on.
  If you are here for another reason, please, go to discussions: https://github.com/anycable/anycable/discussions

  Please, check the documentation website (https://docs.anycable.io/),
  especially, the "Troubleshooting" section (https://docs.anycable.io/troubleshooting)
  before submiting the issue.
-->

### Tell us about your environment

**Ruby version:**
3.1.2

**Rails version:**
7.0.4

**`anycable` gem version:**
1.2.3

**`anycable-rails` gem version:**
1.3.3

**`grpc` gem version:**
1.45.0

### What did you do?

I have been using AnyCable for a while already, but at the moment I am doing general load tests for our app with Locust.

### What did you expect to happen?

RPC process to function correctly with 4GB of RAM allocated per process/pod (Kubernetes).

### What actually happened?

The RPC processes get OOMKilled by Kubernetes very quickly and keep restarting, despite there isn't much activity really. 

Can you advise on how much memory each RPC process is supposed to use? I think that 4GB of RAM are already a lot considering that it's a single Rails process, and I have tried lowering the threads from 40 to 20, with no success. The RPC processes get OOMKilled in a very short time from restarting, so it doesn't happen after a while. Seems like a memory leak or something like that.

Thanks in advance for your help!

comment.body: Thanks @palkan , if it happens again I will try a different version of that gem.

pull_request.title: Increase subnet mask to 24
pull_request.body:
Increase of subnet mask to 24 would gives the possibility to add vSwitch to the network. Currently the network and only existing subnet have the same subnet mask and therefor any other subnet has an overlap and is denied.
With a vSwitch I could probably connect a dedicated server to the cloud.

issue.title: locust k8s operator
issue.body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
Need for flexible, secure and easy to use distributed performance testing solution while enabling keeping in mind points like; cloud governance, k8s resource management, CI compatibility. 


### Describe the solution you'd like
A k8s operator

### Describe alternatives you've considered
HELM. However, this is not optimal as it requires a lot of manipulation and dealing with a lot of different k8s resource types not to mention lack of governance when deployed in an organisation. 

 
### Additional context
In my company, we were interested in cloud based distributed performance testing. We ended up choosing “locust” as a tool and I wrote a kubernetes operator for it. As far as I know and searched, this simply doesn’t exist for locust today.The operator have been running on AWS EKS for months now and it is very stable and performant.

The project was created to provide:
- A friendly user interface "A simple k8s custom resource based on a CRD"
- Ability to run a distributed performance testing
- Only ask for needed cluster permissions (security) 
- Exposing a Prometheus endpoint for test metrics
- Maintain cloud infrastructure governance i.e. when used in an organisation,  it is possible to maintain the governance over the allocated / created resources. 
- Cloud native by design 
- Enablement of performance testing in CI / CD pipelines

The project was inspired after doing an industry study / survey. 
The project was influenced in functionality by the k6 k8s operator.

As the code really doesn't include anything exclusive to the company, Open sourcing it is not a problem and it is something that I would happily do. 

What is the "catch"? 
The only "catch" is that the project is written in Java. That being said, from a user perspective, the interface purely through k8s and users are not exposed to any java code.  This is similar to how k8s and most operators are written in Go but non of k8s users need to know anything about Go. 

Looking forward to your feedback.

comment.body: Hi @AbdelrhmanHamouda ! This looks amazing! I checked the docs and would like to give it a try. How do I open the UI when a test is running?

Invalid Hetzner Cloud token
issue.body:
Hi,

I appreciate your work a lot, I got me going with k3s and I using it constantly for learning purposes. I'm using your project for about a year now and it worked great until I upgraded my hetzner-k3s binary (running on Linux). No matter what I do, I get the error:  Invalid Hetzner Cloud token.

I ran: 
- `hetzner-k3s create-cluster --config-file=config.yaml`
- `hetzner-k3s upgrade-cluster --config-file=config.yaml --new-k3s-version v1.24.4+k3s1`
- I created the config file from scratch by using the example from the instructions
- Created a few new Hetzner Projects and API Tokens at them with read and write permissions
- I checked my env vars (HCLOUD_TOKEN is not set)
- Tried with and without qoutes around the token in the config file
- I tested the Hetzner API by running `curl  -H "Authorization: Bearer $API_TOKEN"   'https://api.hetzner.cloud/v1/server_types'` with the API Token and that works fine. 
- I tried versions 0.6.0 until 0.6.5.pre1
- I even tried the docker version

In al cases I get the error: 
```
Some information in the configuration file requires your attention:
 - Invalid Hetzner Cloud token
```

I hope I didn't make a simple mistake. Do you have any idea what the problem can be?

Thanks in advance

issue.title: Document labels used by Okteto pods
issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Documentation request

**Describe the solution you'd like**
In my case, I use a wrapper around some K8s tools including Okteto to abstract some complexity, and am also using KEDA autoscaling to scale my app. When I start Okteto, the autoscaler interferes because it automatically starts its own non-Okteto pods, so traffic is then split between Okteto pods and the autoscaler pods, causing problems and confusion. For this reason, I changed my CLI so that before starting Okteto it patches the services so that they send traffic only to the Okteto pods, ignoring the autoscaled pods. So I can work with Okteto just fine. 

This wasn't documented, so I had to figure out that Okteto labels the pod for the main service with the label "interactive.dev.okteto.com" and the additional services (as specified in the manifest) with "detached.dev.okteto.com".

By patching my services to use these labels during an Okteto session, I no longer have problems due to the autoscaling.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I couldn't think of an alternative

issue.title: post_create_commands and additional_packages
issue.body:
So, I have added to my config file code bellow. But I see also ability add some packages with `additional_packages`. How that works in different OS? and what about lifecycle? As I understand post_create_commands will be last one for running? If I want to update or add extra nodes will be additional_packages and post_create_commands run for active nodes? 

and how I can labeled nodes in setup way? Does it works https://github.com/vitobotta/hetzner-k3s/issues/98 ?

```
post_create_commands:
- apt update && apt upgrade -y
# Fix for K3s on Debian (Pods can't be scheduled)
- apt -y install apparmor apparmor-utils
#
- apt -y install mc htop vim wget git zsh podman iftop atop lsof fail2ban jq make

comment.body:
Hi, 

- installing packages you specify happens only once the nodes are first created. If you want to upgrade them or install something else after the fact, you need to SSH into the nodes and do it manually.
- The machines are provided by default with Ubuntu unless you specify another image, so the packages and the commands you specify should match that
- If you add new nodes to an existing cluster, it will run the post commands and install the additional packages on them as expected
- the node labelling was introduced in v0.6.2 IIRC but I recommend you use the gem because there are some issues with the binaries. I am currently rewriting the tool in Crystal to be able to offer proper binaries and solve some other issues I have with the Ruby version. If you have problems with 0.6.2 I recommend you stick to a release from before I introduced this changes, 0.5.9 and label the nodes manually for now.

issue.title: Use of cache doesn't seem to speed up much
issue.body:
## Expected Behavior

Using cache should improve performance significantly.

## Actual Behavior

For example I have an endpoint that serializes 7700 records that also include associations. The queries are fast, but generating the serialized response takes 5 seconds at least (I'm already using the oj gem).

I have enabled caching and I can see it creates one individual Redis key for each record and for its associated records too.
But the serialization takes more or less the same time basically.

## Steps to Reproduce the Problem

  1. Add caching configuration to the relevant models (main model as well as the associated models)
  2. Run the serializer the first time, it creates the keys in Redis
  3. Run the serializer the second time with the same data, this is not faster than without caching

## Specifications

  - Version: 2.2.0
  - Ruby version: 3.1.2


Thanks in advance.

issue.body:
NGINX Ingress controller
Release: v1.1.1
nginx version: nginx/1.19.9

**Kubernetes version (use kubectl version):**

**Helm version:**
version.BuildInfo{Version:"v3.7.0", GitCommit:"eeac83883cb4014fe60267ec6373570374ce770b", GitTreeState:"clean", GoVersion:"go1.16.8"}

**Environment:**
- Cloud provider or hardware configuration: GCP GKE
- OS (e.g. from /etc/os-release): Container-Optimized OS from Google 
- Kernel version: 5.4.144+

How was the ingress-nginx-controller installed:
Using helm template , using the command: 

`helm install ingress-nginx ingress-nginx/ingress-nginx --set controller.extraArgs.size-buckets="{0.05,0.1,0.3,0.5,1.0,5,10}"`

Output of 'helm ls -A | grep -i ingress'
ingress-nginx	default  	1       	2022-02-10 12:35:46.167462946 +0200 EET	deployed	ingress-nginx-4.0.17	1.1.1 

**Current State of the controller**:
```
➜  kubectl get pod
NAME                                        READY   STATUS             RESTARTS   AGE
ingress-nginx-controller-7bdc9d4dc8-dtkc2   0/1     CrashLoopBackOff   10         27m
```

```
➜  kubectl describe ingressclasses
Name:         nginx
Labels:       app.kubernetes.io/component=controller
              app.kubernetes.io/instance=ingress-nginx
              app.kubernetes.io/managed-by=Helm
              app.kubernetes.io/name=ingress-nginx
              app.kubernetes.io/part-of=ingress-nginx
              app.kubernetes.io/version=1.1.1
              helm.sh/chart=ingress-nginx-4.0.17

              meta.helm.sh/release-namespace: default
Controller:   k8s.io/ingress-nginx
Events:       <none>

```

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
NGINX Ingress controller

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

unknown flag: --size-buckets
Usage of :
unknown flag: --size-buckets
.....
.....
```

**What happened**:

I installed ingress-nginx using helm and tried to set the flag **size-buckets** as it looks that it exists https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/blob/main/cmd/nginx/flags.go and according that feature described here https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/pull/7171.

The ingress-nginx deployment is successful but the pod is not starting and get the following message in pod logs "unknown flag: --size-buckets".

If try to use other flag, e.g. "enable-metrics" it works and accept the flag.

According the documentation at https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/blob/main/docs/user-guide/cli-arguments.md, the flags time-buckets, length-buckets, size-buckets are not listed in list of arguments. 

So the question is, how can I set these flags?

comment.body: Hi, unfortunately there are some issues with the latest versions introduced with changes I made to be able to offer standalone binaries. I recommend you use v0.5.9 for the time being as I am busy rewriting the tool in Crystal. Rewriting in Crystal makes it easier to produce standalone binaries that will make using the tool easier, since you won't need to set up a Ruby environment or use the Docker image anymore. But this is still a work in progress, so for now please use v0.5.9. Thanks

payload.description: A Ruby gem (and Docker image) to install and manage Kubernetes clusters in Hetzner Cloud using the lightweight distribution k3s by Rancher.

issue.title: Invalid Hetzner Cloud token
issue.body:
Hi,

I appreciate your work a lot, I got me going with k3s and I using it constantly for learning purposes. I'm using your project for about a year now and it worked great until I upgraded my hetzner-k3s binary (running on Linux). No matter what I do, I get the error:  Invalid Hetzner Cloud token.

I ran: 
- `hetzner-k3s create-cluster --config-file=config.yaml`
- `hetzner-k3s upgrade-cluster --config-file=config.yaml --new-k3s-version v1.24.4+k3s1`
- I created the config file from scratch by using the example from the instructions
- Created a few new Hetzner Projects and API Tokens at them with read and write permissions
- I checked my env vars (HCLOUD_TOKEN is not set)
- Tried with and without qoutes around the token in the config file
- I tested the Hetzner API by running `curl  -H "Authorization: Bearer $API_TOKEN"   'https://api.hetzner.cloud/v1/server_types'` with the API Token and that works fine. 
- I tried versions 0.6.0 until 0.6.5.pre1
- I even tried the docker version

In al cases I get the error: 
```
Some information in the configuration file requires your attention:
 - Invalid Hetzner Cloud token
```

I hope I didn't make a simple mistake. Do you have any idea what the problem can be?

Thanks in advance

comment.body: @opsdevit-nl for now yes use an older version. I have started rewriting it in Rust already so the new version should solve several issues.

Is it just a Gem missing or is there something more to why this doesn't work with v0.6.4 binary?
As always thanks for you much appreciated efforts to this very neat tool from belove Finland :smile:

comment.body: Like I said in the other issue I've started rewriting it in Rust to solve these issues and the standalone binaries. It shouldn't take long.

comment.body: I have started to rewrite it in Rust and SSH stuff is much easier and works fine with new keys etc. The library/crate I'm using seems more compatible than Net-SSH in Ruby. I am still new to Rust but I don't think it will take long to rewrite and it will make several things much easier. In the meantime, if you can use the Ruby gem it's better.

comment.body:
I actually did a release already, 0.6.4, which allows you to enable debug logging for SSH connections by setting the environment variable to true

```bash
export SSH_DEBUG=true
```

Run this before creating the cluster and it should produce quite a lot of output which may help find the cause of the issue.

The gem, the binaries, the Homebrew formula and the Docker image have been updated already.

Thanks in advance for checking it out.

comment.body:
Weird, I have never added my SSH key to keychain and I have never been able to reproduce these issues. So annoying....

Tomorrow (time permitting) I will try to produce prerelease binaries with some more debug logging, hoping it might help to find the cause of these issues.

In the meantime, since the standalone binaries are a pretty new thing and might still have issues, do you have a chance to test creating clusters with the regular Ruby gem using  a normal Ruby 2.7.1 environment instead of the standalone binaries? Or with Docker if you cannot set up Ruby. Just to see if the problem occurs only with the standalone binaries.

I wish I were able to reproduce the issue here, it would be much easier to investigate.

issue.title: Support node labels
issue.body: Firstly, thanks a lot for the nice project! Is there any plan to support custom label or annotations for servers, since it's very useful for separating the deployments between nodes. There are a bunch of default labels like instance type, location, hostname but sometime devs need to have some custom labels, too.

comment.body: Hi, does it happen consistently? Have you by chance tried the command multiple times? Github API has an annoying low rate limit if you don't provide a token. I should add a token support to the config.

issue.title: Support node labels
issue.body: Firstly, thanks a lot for the nice project! Is there any plan to support custom label or annotations for servers, since it's very useful for separating the deployments between nodes. There are a bunch of default labels like instance type, location, hostname but sometime devs need to have some custom labels, too.

comment.body: Ok
